awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Restoring natural sleep for adolescents: circadian clock advancement at night assisted with mobile application-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to address chronic sleep deprivation among American teenagers, which has only been made worse by the recent pandemic. Adolescents' natural internal circadian clocks typically run 1-3 hours later than adults, leading to the tendency to stay up late, difficulty falling asleep, insufficient total sleep time, and morning grogginess. This project is designed to improve sleep for adolescents and young adults by advancing their circadian clocks leading to healthier sleep. Today, there are almost 42 million adolescents in the United States aged 11-19, and another 18.9 million young adults aged 20-24, making the commercial potential of this project to be a $10 Billion market opportunity in the United States alone.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is commercializing an innovation in sleep therapy.  Approximately half of all American adolescents and young adults in the United States do not get enough sleep. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia has been somewhat effective when administered by a therapist in person, but the in-person model is not scalable. Lack of sleep can negatively impact physical and neurocognitive development, leading to inability to concentrate, poor grades, higher risk of diabetes and long-term cardiovascular problems, and increased risk of mental health issues, depression, and suicide.  The proposed solution applies recent sleep research and innovates it into a product worn at night and plans to go to market with an integrated solution of both the product hardware and telehealth support. Healthier sleep brought by this solution may lead to better recovery, improved memories and concentration, and enhanced neurocognitive and physical development. It may also reduce the risks for depression and other mental health issues. The enhanced physical and mental health may have other positive impacts in society, for example, reducing healthcare costs and preventing accidents caused by sleep deprivation. Short light pulses may alter circadian phases of human subjects during sleep. Based on light flash technology, the team proposes creating a smart sleep mask that emits light flashes at night during sleep to effectively advance teenagers’ circadian phases without disrupting their daytime activities. This light flash technology will be assisted with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) delivered via a mobile application to promote earlier bedtime and better sleep hygiene.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to explore the feasibility of promoting earlier bedtime for teenagers using a combination of light therapy from the Lumos Smart Sleep Mask and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for insomnia (CBT-i). We planned to create a bench-top prototype that combines the Lumos Mask light therapy with human-led CBT-i that aims to promote earlier bedtime and better sleep, test the feasibility of such combination therapy with the bench-top prototype on a few teenage volunteers, and explore the commercialization feasibility of such combination therapy. 

We assembled a team of experts specializing in teenage sleep and circadian rhythm, including sleep scientists and clinical psychologists with a focus on cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i). We created a bench-top prototype that seamlessly integrates the Lumos Mask light therapy with human-led CBT-i techniques, with the overarching goal of promoting earlier bedtime and ultimately improving sleep outcomes among teenagers. 3 testing subjects were recruited to test the bench-top prototype. Despite the small sample size, we were able to observe substantial improvements in their sleep, including reduction in morning sleepiness and general sleepiness, improved sleep quality, and so on. 

The project encountered several challenges throughout its implementation. Firstly, there were difficulties in ensuring consistent participation from teenagers for engagement and data collection proved challenging. Secondly, recruiting an adequate number of participants posed a significant obstacle, with efforts to attract volunteers meeting with limited success. Finally, many teens interviewed didn't fully grasp the link between their sleep issues and disruptions in circadian rhythms. Some thought lifestyle changes or technology could solve their sleep troubles, ignoring the importance of circadian rhythms. 

In response to the challenges encountered, we implemented several strategies aimed at overcoming these obstacles. To maximize data collection, we streamlined the data collection process through teen-friendly platforms, with constant reminders to reinforce participation and adherence to the study protocol. To overcome the difficulty in recruiting an adequate number of participants, we leveraged all available channels to reach both teenagers and parents. This included outreach through various online platforms, community networks, and educational institutions, as well as communication with participants’ parents for word of mouth recommendations. Despite great experience with the testing and all these efforts, we still only recruited less than half of the planned number. 

The notable improvements demonstrated by our intervention underscore its capacity to address the multifaceted challenges associated with adolescent sleep disturbances, offering a promising avenue for enhancing overall well-being and quality of life among this demographic.

Despite the promising outcomes of our research, we realized the formidable hurdles associated with commercializing this solution. Given the difficulties in engaging stakeholders of this target market, it has become apparent that our team may lack the requisite resources and expertise to effectively navigate the teenager market. 

Recognizing the insufficient commercial feasibility, we decided to pivot on solving sleep problems in adults. Fragmented sleep is a common problem in adults and one of the causes can be circadian rhythm misalignment. The prototype developed in this project with our pivoting effort extends beyond the teenage demographic. It addresses night owls and individuals with similar biological predisposition, as well as other poor sleep due to circadian rhythm misalignment. We successfully constructed an updated prototype and conducted internal testing on a small scale to assess its functionality and effectiveness.

By shifting our target market to adults, we anticipate easier adherence. The relatively straightforward purchase decision process may present a more accessible avenue for market penetration in the adult populations. By acknowledging these nuanced considerations, we remain committed to maximizing the impact of our research findings, whether through commercial ventures or alternative avenues of dissemination and application.

 

We are immensely grateful for the opportunity provided by this grant, which has enabled us to achieve two critical objectives in our research journey.  First, we could show that our idea is promising at the technical level, which can inspire others to explore similar directions. Secondly, the grant has afforded us the opportunity to delve into the exploration of commercial feasibility, a crucial aspect often overlooked in research endeavors. Through market research and stakeholder engagement, we have gained valuable insights into the commercial landscape surrounding our interventions. This understanding has enabled us to pivot and redirect our focus towards more promising avenues, where our efforts are likely to yield tangible results and have a greater impact.
